author: _shemnon
content: I read this as an error in the test specification.  The code before is 0x65 (2 bytes less) in data but has 4 bytes less data.

author: _shemnon
content: 174f5374fce5edbc8e2a8697c15331677e6ebf0b should have two less bytes (4 less Fs)

author: jochembrouwer
content: Right, but AFAIK, Geth reproduces this behavior (? Not entirely sure how tests are generated), so the implementation is wrong? CC <@393119312350543872>

author: dimitry8570
content: The tests are generated by geth evm mostly. For this eip it is a dev branch of that eip, so yes there might be implementation error on either side (geth or other running the test) the goal of the test is to find this disagreement and figure out whats going on.

author: _shemnon
content:
Looks like this violates rule 6 of the container rules in EIP-3540:

> Stray bytes outside of sections MUST NOT be present. This includes trailing bytes after the last section.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Yes I agree, it is invalid EOF. The test is thus incorrect

author: jochembrouwer
content:
<@393119312350543872> I am still a bit confused though, in the "test fillers" you can specify the expected values. I assume that the test generator runs (in this case the `evm` package) a package, and then dumps all storages/accounts and uses that to fill the files in the state tests / blockchain tests (the `post` field in the JSON). What if the package reports differently than the test filler? Does it raise an error?

(If it is ran against `evm` then the geth implementation of the EIP most likely has a bug)

author: dimitry8570
content:
Correct.
Yes if the value reported by evm is different to expect section then there going to be   an error

author: jochembrouwer
content: Ok great, then the Geth implementation which generated the tests most likely has a bug
